headline: OMB Director: Health care, tax reform will happen this year
subHeadline: Mick Mulvaney discusses the timelines for the reforms on "Your World."

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: All right, maybe not so much the Dow, but if you look at the Nasdaq, fully working on the assumption that some goodies are coming from Washington. Are they? The White House budget director, Mick Mulvaney, joining me earlier on Fox Business to say, well, when it comes to health care, tax reform, they are. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: They assume they're going to get tax reform, they're going to see it this year. Are they?

utterances.speaker: MICK MULVANEY, WHITE HOUSE BUDGET DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: They are. I also think they are going to get health care reform. And I think some of the challenges you're seeing in the Senate mimic some of the challenges we saw back in March in the House. There was a time in, I think, mid-March where a lot of folks said that health care was dead, it would never get out of the House. And a couple weeks later, it did.  Seeing a lot of those same dynamics in the Senate right now. And I think, ultimately, a health care package will pass out of the Senate, will pass the House, will be signed by the president.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: When? When do you think it will be?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: You know, I actually think they have to do something before September.   As a former elected official, I really wouldn't want to go home without having followed through on my biggest promise. What do you tell people? Even if somebody else is the person who killed it, how do you defend your party, as a Republican, by saying, well, thanks for giving us the House, the Senate and the White House, but we didn't actually follow through on our biggest promise? I think that weights -- weighs very heavily on many of my Senate friends, and it should. And that's why I think you will see health care. And I do see -- think you will see tax reform shortly thereafter.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: As a former founding member actually of the Freedom Caucus, the conservative -- group of conservative who are not keen on, you know, more spending or even keeping tax hikes in effect, they seem to be open to the Senate measure, the one that didn't seem to be going anywhere, that would include the taxes on the upper income for, you know, the Medicare and related expenses. Now, how did you feel about that? How would you feel if a final draft or something that comes out of the Senate includes keeping taxes like that in there?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: Sure, a couple difference responses to that.  At one hand, politics is the art of the possible. And if that's what it takes to get ObamaCare to get repealed, that certainly wouldn't bother me, if I put my old Freedom Caucus had on. I think a lot of my friends in the House feel the same way.   But I also add to that the fact that tax reform is coming next. We know that it is. It may be a second bite at the apple to try and fix different parts of the tax code. So, it doesn't at all surprise me that that hasn't killed the bill in the Senate, or at least it doesn't look like it's killing the bill in the Senate.  And I do encourage the Senate to go ahead. If that's what they think it takes to get rid of ObamaCare on that side of the building, they should go ahead and press on with that, and we will deal with taxes next -- in the next chance we get.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you could live with that yourself, as the budget director?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: Again, as the budget director, as a member of Congress, what am I -- former member Congress -- what am I interested in? Getting rid of ObamaCare, because I think, more than anybody else, we get down in the weeds over here, and we see what the existence of ObamaCare is doing to people.  There's so much talk about, oh, how many people will or won't be covered, when what we see every single day is people back home every single day actually losing their coverage right now, in the real world, under ObamaCare. So getting rid of that has to be the highest priority.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: If I can get back to tax cut thing, I find that a lot of Democrats say they want to work with Republicans. A number of Republicans say that, all right, we will throw an olive branch to you.  And the latest do so, sir, was Chris Collins, the moderate Republican of the state of New York. I want you to react to this. This is in a conversation on our air about how to proceed in a bipartisan way on tax cuts.

utterances.speaker: REP. CHRIS COLLINS, R-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: There is the potential of getting some Democrats to come on board. It might not be as massive a cut as some of us would like, but if we can get those corporate rates down, that money would be reinvested in jobs and the economy.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We could have and America would actually applaud something called a bipartisan tax reform.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: They would actually think, oh, my God, Congress and D.C., they're finally doing their job.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You know what I read into that? It might not be as massive a tax cut. In other words, to bring Democrats on board, assuming that's what you need, you can't have as big a tax cut. Do you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I think what you're hearing from the administration, we're all on the same page. I talked to Director Cohn this morning. I have talked to Secretary Mnuchin about this. We have had regular conversations with the president.  We want the biggest tax cut, we want the most sweeping tax reform that can actually pass. I happen to personally think, as I stand here, I disagree with my colleague, my former colleague, say I think we get a better tax package out of a Republican plan. But if there's an argument to be made for a bigger, bolder, better tax reform plan, tax cut plan coming out of a bipartisan deal, that's certainly something that we would consider.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: It doesn't sound like it would be bigger and bolder, though. Anything bipartisan would water it down. Right?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. And I think -- and that's my gut reaction. I'm trying to be gracious to my former colleague. But I think as soon as you invite 10, 12, 15 Democrats to the table, you're going to see it simply get watered down.  And we can't have it. We have to get back to a healthy American economy. You have to get to 3 percent growth. That's what MAGAnomics is all about. And just fiddling around on the edges of the tax code isn't going to get us there.  So, I think we press on with a Republican bill, while all the time listening to Democrats if they have ideas of how to go bigger or go better.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Do you think the rich should get a tax cut?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I think we should do whatever it takes to get 3 percent growth. Part of that means I have to have productivity to grow up. The two primary factors in economic growth, GDP growth, would be population growth plus productivity.   When we nail down on productivity, we look at things like private investment, capital investment, investing in capital. And anything that we can do in the tax code at the corporate level, at the pass-through level, at the top levels, even at middle-class America levels, whatever encourages more investment in capital, drives up productivity, and that's what will drive our GDP growth.  So, again, what is MAGAnomics all about? Looking at everything through the prism of how do we get to 3 percent growth. And that's how we will look at any tax reform proposals.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, that area of growth is concentrated among the very wealthy. They would get you the bang for that buck, right?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I need productivity growth. I need everybody to be more productive.   We need folks to come back to work. That's why welfare is part of MAGAnomics. Welfare reform is, getting rid, as I said before, about ObamaCare and getting rid of that...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you still want across-the-board tax cuts?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I want as much as we can possibly get out of the House and the Senate.   So, I think the proposal that we have put forward is still on the table about the 15 percent corporate cuts of corporate rates, the...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes, you mentioned the 15 percent, by the way. And others that I hear on the Hill are starting -- their starting point seems to be 20, even 25 percent. I believe Orrin Hatch had mentioned even 25 percent.  Is there a point at which you say, no, no, no, our minimum is this?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I think it's a negotiation.  I'm happy to -- if I'm starting at 15, and they are starting at 20, I'm pretty sure that 17-and-a-half sounds like a pretty good number.

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: So, it's just part of the negotiation.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.  But let me ask you a little bit. With your recent budget and the ideas that you have that Nancy Pelosi has come down on you pretty hard and fast, that you know what it does, referring to the Republican budget. It requires more military might. It takes us down the wrong path. She goes on to say: "This was supposed to be a budget that prevents the spread of violence. Instead, they have a budget that stirs it up." Your reaction?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. I -- you know, how do I react to Mrs. Pelosi? It's sort of a never-ending list of things I could say.  The bottom line is, what do you expect? It's been a long time since the minority leader in the House had anything constructive to say about the process. And while I respect her position, I don't look to her for advice on my budget.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, but whether it's the House budget she's railing against or your budget that she said was a nonstarter, and now the Democratic leaders up talking their own plans to revive the economy, they say it shouldn't be done helping the rich. You say what?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I say that that is a speech that she probably wrote 57 years ago, when she got to Congress, and she's used it every single year that a House -- that a Republican administration has trotted out a budget, every single year that the Republicans in the House trotted out a budget.  It's old talking points. It's not constructive. There's some really good ideas in there that I think the Democrats could focus on as a place for us to get together, for example, the commitment we make on apprenticeship training, some of the commitments we make on expanding school choice. Why aren't we talking about the things in the budget that the Democrats might be able to support, instead of having them pull out the same speeches they have used since I have been in Washington for seven years now?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, I will put you down as a maybe on Nancy Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Now, finally, sir, I would be remiss if I didn't mention these latest rumors going back and forth that the president is throwing out Rudy Giuliani's name as a possible attorney general. I only mention that in the scheme of the criticism he dumped on his attorney general for the way he handled the Russia recusal thing. But I wonder, as a loyal confidant and now as OMB director, and other Cabinet members feel that the president might not have your back?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: I couldn't disagree with that more, more fervently.  I unveiled a fairly aggressive budget, Neil, a couple weeks ago, a couple months ago. You saw it. You saw the heat that I took on the Hill for it, even from some of my members of my own party. The president had my back 100 percent of the time. So, I judge people by what they do, not what other people say about them. And this president has always had my back, and I have no reason to believe it would ever be -- it would ever be any different.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But people aren't freaking out there?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: We don't freak out at OMB.

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.sentences: We're the Office of Management and Budget, not the office of freaking out. We work. We work for our paychecks. We work for a living over here and we don't get caught up in a lot of the things that the media wants us to talk about. Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: You know, I actually think they have to do something before September. As a former elected official, I really wouldn't want to go home without having followed through on my biggest promise. What do you tell people? Even if somebody else is the person who killed it, how do you defend your party, as a Republican, by saying, well, thanks for giving us the House, the Senate and the White House, but we didn't actually follow through on our biggest promise? I think that weights -- weighs very heavily on many of my Senate friends, and it should. And that's why I think you will see health care. And I do see -- think you will see tax reform shortly thereafter.

utterances.utterance: As a former founding member actually of the Freedom Caucus, the conservative -- group of conservative who are not keen on, you know, more spending or even keeping tax hikes in effect, they seem to be open to the Senate measure, the one that didn't seem to be going anywhere, that would include the taxes on the upper income for, you know, the Medicare and related expenses. utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: Sure, a couple difference responses to that. At one hand, politics is the art of the possible. And if that's what it takes to get ObamaCare to get repealed, that certainly wouldn't bother me, if I put my old Freedom Caucus had on. I think a lot of my friends in the House feel the same way. But I also add to that the fact that tax reform is coming next. We know that it is. It may be a second bite at the apple to try and fix different parts of the tax code. So, it doesn't at all surprise me that that hasn't killed the bill in the Senate, or at least it doesn't look like it's killing the bill in the Senate. And I do encourage the Senate to go ahead. If that's what they think it takes to get rid of ObamaCare on that side of the building, they should go ahead and press on with that, and we will deal with taxes next -- in the next chance we get.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But you could live with that yourself, as the budget director?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: Again, as the budget director, as a member of Congress, what am I -- former member Congress -- what am I interested in? Getting rid of ObamaCare, because I think, more than anybody else, we get down in the weeds over here, and we see what the existence of ObamaCare is doing to people. There's so much talk about, oh, how many people will or won't be covered, when what we see every single day is people back home every single day actually losing their coverage right now, in the real world, under ObamaCare. So getting rid of that has to be the highest priority.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: If I can get back to tax cut thing, I find that a lot of Democrats say they want to work with Republicans. A number of Republicans say that, all right, we will throw an olive branch to you. And the latest do so, sir, was Chris Collins, the moderate Republican of the state of New York. I want you to react to this. This is in a conversation on our air about how to proceed in a bipartisan way on tax cuts.

utterances.speaker: REP. CHRIS COLLINS, R-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: There is the potential of getting some Democrats to come on board. It might not be as massive a cut as some of us would like, but if we can get those corporate rates down, that money would be reinvested in jobs and the economy.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: We could have and America would actually applaud something called a bipartisan tax reform.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: They would actually think, oh, my God, Congress and D.C., they're finally doing their job.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know what I read into that? It might not be as massive a tax cut. In other words, to bring Democrats on board, assuming that's what you need, you can't have as big a tax cut. Do you agree with that?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I think what you're hearing from the administration, we're all on the same page. I talked to Director Cohn this morning. I have talked to Secretary Mnuchin about this. We have had regular conversations with the president. We want the biggest tax cut, we want the most sweeping tax reform that can actually pass. I happen to personally think, as I stand here, I disagree with my colleague, my former colleague, say I think we get a better tax package out of a Republican plan. But if there's an argument to be made for a bigger, bolder, better tax reform plan, tax cut plan coming out of a bipartisan deal, that's certainly something that we would consider.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: It doesn't sound like it would be bigger and bolder, though. Anything bipartisan would water it down. Right?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I think -- and that's my gut reaction. I'm trying to be gracious to my former colleague. But I think as soon as you invite 10, 12, 15 Democrats to the table, you're going to see it simply get watered down. And we can't have it. We have to get back to a healthy American economy. You have to get to 3 percent growth. That's what MAGAnomics is all about. And just fiddling around on the edges of the tax code isn't going to get us there. So, I think we press on with a Republican bill, while all the time listening to Democrats if they have ideas of how to go bigger or go better.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Do you think the rich should get a tax cut?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I think we should do whatever it takes to get 3 percent growth. Part of that means I have to have productivity to grow up. The two primary factors in economic growth, GDP growth, would be population growth plus productivity. When we nail down on productivity, we look at things like private investment, capital investment, investing in capital. And anything that we can do in the tax code at the corporate level, at the pass-through level, at the top levels, even at middle-class America levels, whatever encourages more investment in capital, drives up productivity, and that's what will drive our GDP growth. So, again, what is MAGAnomics all about? Looking at everything through the prism of how do we get to 3 percent growth. And that's how we will look at any tax reform proposals.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, that area of growth is concentrated among the very wealthy. They would get you the bang for that buck, right?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I need productivity growth. I need everybody to be more productive. We need folks to come back to work. That's why welfare is part of MAGAnomics. Welfare reform is, getting rid, as I said before, about ObamaCare and getting rid of that...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But you still want across-the-board tax cuts?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I want as much as we can possibly get out of the House and the Senate. So, I think the proposal that we have put forward is still on the table about the 15 percent corporate cuts of corporate rates, the...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, you mentioned the 15 percent, by the way. And others that I hear on the Hill are starting -- their starting point seems to be 20, even 25 percent. I believe Orrin Hatch had mentioned even 25 percent. Is there a point at which you say, no, no, no, our minimum is this?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I think it's a negotiation. I'm happy to -- if I'm starting at 15, and they are starting at 20, I'm pretty sure that 17-and-a-half sounds like a pretty good number.

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: So, it's just part of the negotiation.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right. But let me ask you a little bit. With your recent budget and the ideas that you have that Nancy Pelosi has come down on you pretty hard and fast, that you know what it does, referring to the Republican budget. It requires more military might. It takes us down the wrong path.

utterances.speaker: She goes on to say
utterances.utterance: "This was supposed to be a budget that prevents the spread of violence. Instead, they have a budget that stirs it up." Your reaction?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: Yes. I -- you know, how do I react to Mrs. Pelosi? It's sort of a never-ending list of things I could say. The bottom line is, what do you expect? It's been a long time since the minority leader in the House had anything constructive to say about the process. And while I respect her position, I don't look to her for advice on my budget.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, but whether it's the House budget she's railing against or your budget that she said was a nonstarter, and now the Democratic leaders up talking their own plans to revive the economy, they say it shouldn't be done helping the rich. You say what?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I say that that is a speech that she probably wrote 57 years ago, when she got to Congress, and she's used it every single year that a House -- that a Republican administration has trotted out a budget, every single year that the Republicans in the House trotted out a budget. It's old talking points. It's not constructive. There's some really good ideas in there that I think the Democrats could focus on as a place for us to get together, for example, the commitment we make on apprenticeship training, some of the commitments we make on expanding school choice. Why aren't we talking about the things in the budget that the Democrats might be able to support, instead of having them pull out the same speeches they have used since I have been in Washington for seven years now?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, I will put you down as a maybe on Nancy Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Now, finally, sir, I would be remiss if I didn't mention these latest rumors going back and forth that the president is throwing out Rudy Giuliani's name as a possible attorney general. I only mention that in the scheme of the criticism he dumped on his attorney general for the way he handled the Russia recusal thing. But I wonder, as a loyal confidant and now as OMB director, and other Cabinet members feel that the president might not have your back?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: I couldn't disagree with that more, more fervently. I unveiled a fairly aggressive budget, Neil, a couple weeks ago, a couple months ago. You saw it. You saw the heat that I took on the Hill for it, even from some of my members of my own party. The president had my back 100 percent of the time. So, I judge people by what they do, not what other people say about them. And this president has always had my back, and I have no reason to believe it would ever be -- it would ever be any different.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But people aren't freaking out there?

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: We don't freak out at OMB.

utterances.speaker: MULVANEY
utterances.utterance: We're the Office of Management and Budget, not the office of freaking out. We work. We work for our paychecks. We work for a living over here and we don't get caught up in a lot of the things that the media wants us to talk about. Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC.
